description.narrative:
The Gender Action Learning System (GALS) was developed under Oxfam's WEMAN programme since 2008 with Linda Mayoux and partners. Since 2009 IFAD has been promoting the use of GALS and other innovative household methodologies (HHM) as a mechanism to achieve asignificant and sustainable reduction in rural poverty. GALS and the "Household Mentoring approach" developed as part of the Agricultural Support Programme (ASP) supported by Swedish Sida in Zambia are among the two most comprehensive methodologies promoted by IFAD.
H HM position poor female and male smallholder farmers as drivers of their own development rather than recipients of aid or victims. It enables them to identify and address obstacles in their environment, change gender relations in the household and community, negotiate better prices for their products or better service delivery, and strengthen their asset base1. HHM have been successfully applied in a number of countries and can effectively be integrated into agricultural extension, ruralfinance and value chain development.They increase the pro-poor impact of such economic interventions and can contribute significantly to IFAD´s goal of helping 80 million people out of poverty.
For this project a consortium was formed with local CSOsin Rwanda, Burundi and DRC to promote sharing ofexperiences between three countries, capitalise on the opportunities for linking with IFAD programmes in these countries and to bring in more practitioners from Francophone West Africa. The selection of these three countries was based on the demand to provide materials in French and to have locations where participants can learn from HMM in practice. The experience and expertise built up withpartners and their community groups in Rwanda will be beneficialfor the other two countries but also for IFAD staff from other Francophone countries.
In 2017 Oxfam in DRC transitioned to Oxfam Great Britain DRC.

participating-org.narrative: In the framework of Oxfam Internationals (OI) joint work, Oxfam Great Britain has made available its infrastructure to allow for the implementation of the Joint OI HIV and AIDS mainstreaming Project in East and Central Africa. Whereas in other Eastern and CentralAfrican countries this same model is used (e.g. Uganda, Tanzania, Kenya), other models are used in the cases of Rwanda and Burundi,where ACORD as Oxfam Novib's counterpart leads the project. Oxfam Great Britain has recently moved its main headquarters to Goma, from where the HIV and AIDS project will be managed. Oxfam Great Britain disposes of efficient administrative and financial structures and methods, including annual auditing.
